Award.AwardTitle: Towards a Computationally Efficient Recursive Model Reduction and Controller Design Approach for Spatially Distributed Processes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research project is to relax the requirements of data-based nonlinear order reduction methods and extend their applicability towards the control and optimization of dissipative partial differential equation (PDE) systems arising in the context of spatially distributed processes. To achieve this objective, the research will initially focus on creating a computationally efficient data-driven algorithm for: a) the derivation of nonlinear low-order, approximate models for dissipative PDE systems that are specifically tailored for control and optimization purposes, and b) characterization of the error between the low-order model and PDE system solutions. Subsequently, the research will focus on the synthesis of practically implementable feedback control structures that can deal with the issues of nonlinearity, model uncertainty, constrains and limited measurement availability. Concurrently, computational issues of optimization/optimal operation policies for spatially distributed processes will be resolved. This will be achieved via the derivation of a systematic scheme for the formulation of computationally efficient dynamic optimization problems that are amenable to standard search algorithms.


The research results will be transferred into the industrial sector through the development and dissemination of software with a transparent user-machine interaction interface. Analyzing, optimizing and tightly controlling transport-reaction processes will benefit key processes of a wide range of industries such as lithographic reactors for microelectronics and photovoltaics fabrication and advanced catalytic reactors and industrial glass furnaces. Moreover, numerous activities will be pursued to integrate the research with education including incorporation of research results in optimization and control courses, undergraduate student participation in research through the honors program, and the development of educational tools such as matlab add-ons, java applets and wikis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project under award 13-00322 considered fabrication processes in the electronics, pharmaceutical and chemical industries that involve complex transport and reaction phenomena. Such processes are mathematically described by nonlinear dissipative partial differential equations (DPDEs). For complex processes, data-driven order reduction techniques are used to discretize them, where the ad-hoc nature of this order reduction step is usually circumvented through extensive simulations.

The objective was thus to develop a systematic data-driven order reduction algorithm that is tailored for control and optimization of nonlinear dissipative partial differential equation systems.

Focusing on DPDE system, the main outcome of the project is the development of the “adaptive proper orthogonal decomposition” (APOD) methodology to identify appropriate basis functions to approximate the DPDEs by a finite number of ordinary differential equations (ODEs). This approximation is constructed using Galerkin’s method. The ODEs are subsequently used to automatically design the observer and controller pair. A schematic of the closed-loop system Is presented in Figure 1. The novel components of the control system are the adaptive model order reduction (AMORe) component and the supervisory controller. The idea is that as the process evolves, the control system periodically obtains detailed information about the process state, which is used to evaluate the approximation by the supervisory controller. When the approximation is deemed to be inaccurate, APOD is employed along with the recent detailed information to refine the basis functions and derive a new Galerkin approximation. The reconfigured observer and controller pair are then activated to continue regulating the process.

The basis refinement algorithm is presented in Figure 2. The advantages of the developed algorithm lie in that algebraic operations are used to refine the basis functions and the model is refined on demand, only when it is necessary. Under relaxed conditions, the AMORe/APOD algorithm with Luenberger observers and Lyapunov controllers are shown to be sufficient to regulate the process.

Further refinements of the main algorithm include modified APOD (shown in Figure 3), which is applicable to process with fast transients. It retains the algebraic nature and computational efficiency of APOD while simultaneously deriving global basis functions that have a wider region of attraction. DAPOD is also introduced which has improved accuracy guarantees at the cost of higher computational cost. To address issues of model uncertainty adaptive model reduction algorithms are also combined with adaptive controllers. The issue of incomplete detailed information of the system state is addressed via GAPOD (gappy APOD), combined with robust controllers.

From an academic perspective the outcomes of the project include the development of one graduate elective course on control of distributed parameter systems, presented to mechanical engineering and chemical engineering students. Three graduate students successfully defended their doctoral thesis on the development of APOD and GAPOD, modified APOD and adaptive control, and DAPOD and DEIM algorithms and their application to chemical end electronics processes. Outcomes include thirteen articles in international scientific journals, fourteen juried conference proceeding papers and a total of thirty oral presentations at international conferences. Three undergraduate students were also mentored while pursuing application of the project outcomes to industrially relevant processes.
